Susanne Roesner

Writing about Human-Nature Relationships & From More-Than-Human Perspectives

Image by Filip Zrnzević on Unsplash

About Susanne

Writing Interests

Susanne Roesner is a writer and academic, currently working on a novel about hopeful, sustainable, and resilient visions of the future.

She writes in English and German and has written short stories, essays, and (blog-) articles for the Swansea Review, the Richard Burton Archives, and the magazine Der PalmenGarten 2024.

Susanne Roesner schreibt Kurzgeschichten, Essays und an einem Roman, der Fragen zu hoffnungsvollen, nachhaltigen und resilienten Zukunftsvisionen stellt.

Sie schreibt in deutscher und englischer Sprache und hat Blogartikel und Essays für die Swansea Review, die Richard Burton Archives für die Zeitschrift Der PalmenGarten 2024 verfasst.

Susanne's Short Stories

Human and Non-Human Emotions

Of Creatures and Caretakers

An oak tree's perspective, selected as runner up in the 2023 Solarpunk Showcase

Network whisperings are delighting her soul. She reaches out to her kin and exchanges sustenance through the embrace of wide-reaching arms. A new bloom is mutually shared, and layers of soil are teeming with life, infinitely invigorating.

“We are growing,” they whisper, taking her many hands to guide her. She feels the pinpricks of smaller meshwork connecting with her own. There, supported by many loving arms a new born oak sapling pokes its head through the soil, moist with morning dew. Soon four luscious green leaves are drinking in the sunlight, spreading out next to meadow foxtail and springy turf moss.

“There are more,” they whisper, and she sees new life taking root by the brook. Silver birch trees and trembling aspen have returned, their roots and stems, branches, leaves, and crowns now, for the first time, stretching freely.

Image by Dulcey Lima on Unsplash

Essay

Insekten in Gegenwart und Zukunft

Wer summt im Garten der Zukunft?

Wie können Kunst und Literatur unsere Wahrnehmung schärfen und uns helfen, hoffnungsvolle Szenarien für die Zukunft zu entwickeln?

Ein sonniger Juli-Nachmittag im Botanischen Garten Frankfurt, der ideale Zeitpunkt für einen Fotographie-Workshop rund um Blüten und Bestäuber: Durch die Linsen unserer Kameras beobachten wir die feinen Bewegungen verschiedener Insekten im Arzneipflanzengarten und tauchen ein in eine Welt, die wir im Alltag schnell mal übersehen.
